newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish c.bank sold dlrs for lira-bankers.
newsitem.headline: Turkish c.bank sold dlrs for lira-bankers.

text.p: The Turkish central bank sold dollar for lira in late morning trade on Monday, in a bid to support the currency after the S&P downgraded Turkey's long-term foreign currency rating on Friday, bankers said.
The lira firmed to 105,330 against the dollar at noon from an earlier level 105,400. It was down on Friday's 104,160 close.
Bankers said a higher dollar/mark parity also undermined the lira in morning trade.
"A downgrading was expected (since last week), so the markets remained calm although the dollar opened sharply higher and Treasury-bill yields rose," said a private banker.

The S&P cut Turkey's long-term foreign currency rating to "single B" from "single B-plus" and affirmed its "single-B" short-term foreign currency rating on Friday. The outlook on Turkey's long-term rating was stable, it said.
Yields on the bond market rose by between two and three points across the board.
"The downgrading made the bond market nervous and sparked selling which caused yields to rise. The market has not yet set a direction," said a bond market trader.
The yield on the most heavily traded 3 September 1997 paper leapt to 116.03 percent from 113.62 and the second most active 4 June 1997 yielded 114.99 percent, up from 112.70 on Friday.
Overnight money traded at 77.50 and 77.75 percent after the market opened with a 24.8 trillion lira surplus, up sharply from Friday's 59.98 percent average.
Bankers expected the markets to remain calm, citing strong central bank currency reserves and financial institutions' experiences from 1994 financial crises when they posted sharp losses.
